journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

title-group.article-title: Mathematical formulae to calculate the theoretical range of motion of prosthetic hip implants with non-circular neck geometry

contrib-group.aff: Department of Surgical Sciences, University of Bergen, Bergen, Norway

author-notes.corresp: Peter Ellison, Biomaterials, Department of Surgical Sciences, University of Bergen, 5020 Bergen, Norway. Email: Peter.ellison@kir.uib.no

abstract.p: Component design and position are major factors in achieving adequate range of motion post hip replacement. It is therefore important to understand how implant design and positioning impact the motion available before impingement. The Yoshimine–Ginbayashi equations allow the theoretical range of motion of total hip replacements to be calculated accurately and quickly. However, a significant limitation of these equations is that they can only be applied to femoral neck geometry with a circular cross section. The objective of the present study was to reformulate the equations to allow fast and accurate calculation of the range of motion for prostheses with any femoral neck geometry. Using vector analysis, formulae were derived such that the range of motion could be calculated from the cross section of the neck at the point of impingement, cup radius at the point of impingement, cup inclination angle, cup anteversion angle, neck angle of the femoral component from the transverse plane and neck anteversion. The range of motion was calculated for circular, truncated circle and free-form femoral neck geometry under a range of component positions. These values were successfully compared with those measured from analysis of solid models in three-dimensional computer-aided design software. The method of analysis presented offers a powerful new technique enabling hip prostheses to be analysed in an accurate and efficient manner, therefore facilitating optimisation of the design geometry, assessment of existing pre-clinical designs and clinical pre- or postoperative evaluation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Adequate range of motion (ROM) following total hip replacement (THR) or hip resurfacing (HR) is important for successful clinical performance. A reduced ROM due to poor design or inappropriate positioning may lead to impingement between the femoral component/neck, which can lead to instability, accelerated wear and unexplained pain.1 Typically, the ROM of a hip replacement implant is obtained through analysis of three-dimensional (3D) solid models in computer-aided design (CAD) software,2,3 which is both time and labour intensive. Yoshimine and Ginbayashi4 presented a series of mathematical formulae allowing the theoretical ROM for THR to be calculated directly in a simple and accurate manner, thereby facilitating parametric analysis of the relationship between implant position and ROM with minimal computing power or specialist software.5,6 However, application of these equations is limited to femoral necks of circular cross section. The purpose of this study is to reformulate the Yoshimine–Ginbayashi equations such that they can be applied to femoral geometry with non-uniform cross-sectional radii, therefore making them applicable to commercially available designs of THR and also HR.

sec.title: Methods and materials
sec.p: The position of the neck and the cup can be described using (1) cup inclination (α), (2) cup anteversion (β), (3) the neck angle of the femoral component from the transverse plane (a) and (4) neck anteversion (b) (Figures 1 and 2). When the head is located in the cup, the rotational centre of the bearing is at the centre of the head, and therefore, the point of impingement of the neck on the cup, not necessarily the inner most rim of the cup, can be expressed as the dot product of a vector with a magnitude equal to the radius of the inner rim, G, and a vector defining the position of the cup, H. This can be defined in a global coordinate system by

caption.p: Left hip viewed along the X-axis. The position of the acetabular cup is defined using cup inclination, α, and cup anteversion, β. The inclusion angle of the cup is denoted with the abbreviation ic.
The orientation of the femoral neck is defined by the angle of the neck axis to the transverse plane, −a, and neck anteversion, b.

sec.p: Assuming that the neutral position of the cup is with the opening facing downwards, H can be expressed as a function of the position of the cup by rotating the cup by α about X-axis, and rotating the cup anteriorly by β about the line Z = y⋅tan α (Figure 1).
Knowing the maximum angle of the rotational movement in the cup (A), where A = 360 −ic (Figure 1), allows the coordinates of the point of impingement on the cup to be defined as

The site of impingement on the neck can be determined by a vector with a magnitude equal to the point of impingement on the cup. Given that the radial coordinate of the neck’s cross section, r, is a known function of the polar angle, θ, about the shafts centreline, the position (Figure 3) where the neck axis is pointing in the positive y direction (Figure 4), any point on the neck B0(x0, y0, z0) can be defined as

caption.p: Cross section of the femoral neck at the level of potential impingement on the cup for the three geometries investigated (a) circular neck, (b) truncated circle and (c) free-form (exact definition of this geometry is provided in Appendix 2). In each case, the polar angle, θ, was measured in an anti-clockwise direction from the positive Z-axis.
Diagram illustrating the neutral position of the femoral neck cross section in three-dimensional space that is defined by points B0(x0, y0, z0).

sec.p: Therefore, the neck’s starting position can be determined by rotating B0 by −a degrees about the X-axis and b degrees about the Z-axis (Figure 2)

If the neck is rotated in isolation about any one of the principal axes, the position of a fixed point on the neck along that axis will remain constant, for example, each potential site of impingement on the neck will have a constant y coordinate if it is rotated about the flexion–extension axis. Combining this information with equations (1), (4) and (6) allows three simultaneous quadratic equations to be derived of which the three unknowns are the coordinates of the two intersecting points of the cup rim and the neck (Figure 5). The rotation of the neck from its starting position until impingement can be determined by calculating the dot product of the vector defining the starting position of the neck (equation (6)) and that defining the site of impingement on the cup. If these equations are solved for each point on the femoral neck where impingement is possible, the actual rotation before impingement will be the resulting functions’ minima.

caption.p: Left hip replacement, the point of impingement on the cup and the flexion–extension cone for a chosen point on the femoral neck. The flexion and extension angles when the chosen point of the neck will impinge on the cup are shown as ∠LCB and ∠MCB, respectively.

Full derivation of these equations is provided in Appendix 1.

The presented equations were used to calculate the extremes of FE, EX, IR, ER, ADD, ABD, IRfl90 and ERfl90. motion of the femoral neck before impingement. Three difference neck cross sections (Figure 3) were considered at seven different parameter sets (α = 30°– 60°; β = 10°– 30°; a = 54°; b = 12°–30°). The circular and truncated circle neck cross sections represented typical commercially available designs of femoral stems. The free-form cross section was used to test the versatility of the vector analysis. An interval of 1° in polar angle was used for all calculations. For circular and truncated neck cross sections, the relationship between the radial and angular coordinates was calculated explicitly from technical drawings (Figure 3). For the free-form neck, the radial coordinate was measured from a CAD model at 72 different polar angles, the spacing of which was reduced to 1° through linear interpolation. The exact values of the radial and polar coordinates used for the free-form neck are provided in Appendix 2. A cup with a 14 mm inner radius and 180° inclusion angle was used for all calculations.

The cross product of the vector defining the starting position of the neck and that defining the site of impingement was calculated to check the sign of the calculated angles. The accuracy of the results was compared to those measured using CAD software for the different configurations in order to verify the accuracy of the equations. The geometry of the cup and necks was created in Creo Elements/Pro (PTC, Massachusetts, USA), and the neck was rotated at increments of 0.36° about each principal axis. The rotation at impingement was taken as the 0.36° range over which intersection of the cup and neck occurred.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The extreme rotational motions before impingement for each neck design at the seven parameter sets are presented in Table 1. In each case, the result that is calculated through vector analysis is within the 0.36° range of that calculated from the CAD software. FL, ER and ADD are inversely proportional to the inclination and neck angles from the transverse plane, and are proportional to the cup anteversion. EX, IR, and ABD are proportional to the inclination and neck angles from the transverse plane, and are inversely proportional to the cup anteversion.

caption.p: Values of extreme rotational motions calculated through vector analysis and analysis of three-dimensional solid models in CAD software

fn.p: EX: extension: FL: flexion; IR: internal rotation; ABD: abduction; ADD: adduction; CAD: computer-aided design.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The Yoshimine–Ginbayashi4 equations allow accurate and fast calculation of the ROM of total hip prostheses depending on the cup position, neck position and component geometry. This analysis allows a significant advantage over the more common technique employing 3D CAD software to analyse ROM, which is labour intensive, requires proprietary software and requires expert knowledge of the analysis software used. However, as the equations are based on vector analysis of the mid-shaft of the femoral neck and the technical ROM of the prosthesis, they can only be applied to circular neck geometry, and application is not possible to many specific designs of THR, or post HR. This article presents the equations in a reconstituted form, which allows the ROM of non-uniform neck geometry to be calculated quickly and accurately. Using these formulae, it is possible to analyse ROM for any design of THR or HR based on six parameters: cross section of the neck at the point of impingement, cup radius at the point of impingement, cup inclination angle, cup anteversion angle, the neck angle of the femoral component from the transverse plane and neck anterversion. This new approach increases the scope of application of the original analysis, thereby facilitating more detailed investigation of the impact of neck geometry on ROM and clinical investigation of kinematics post hip replacement.

As with the original equations, this analysis is based on the assumption that the point of impingement on the cup is axisymmetric about an axis that passes through the joints rotation centre. This may be invalid if the cross section of the neck changes along its length, or if the detailed design of the cup rim causes the radius of the point of neck impingement, |G|, to vary with neck radius. A method describing how to test this assumption is provided in Appendix 3. A further assumption is that only the impingement between the femoral component and the acetabular component is considered. Any other potential bony or soft-tissue impingement occurring will occur prior to that described in this study, and therefore, the possibility of subluxation or dislocation becomes much greater.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The method of analysis presented offers a powerful new technique enabling hip prostheses to be analysed in an accurate and efficient manner, therefore facilitating optimisation of the design geometry, assessment of the existing pre-clinical designs and clinical pre- or postoperative evaluation. This is a substantial improvement over existing techniques, which have limited clinical application to commercially available designs of prostheses, requiring specialist software and are both time and labour intensive.

sec.title: Derivation of the equations of range of motion
sec.p: The position of the neck and cup can be described using (1) cup inclination (α), (2) cup anteversion (β), (3) neck angle of the femoral component from the transverse plane (a) and (4) neck anteversion (b) (Figures 1 and 2). When the head is located in the cup, the rotational centre of the bearing is at the centre of the head, and therefore, the point of impingement on the cup, typically the inner rim, can be expressed as the dot product of a vector with the magnitude of the radius of the inner rim, G and a vector defining the position of the cup, H. This can be defined in a global coordinate system by

Assuming that the neutral position of the cup is with the opening facing downwards, H can be expressed as a function of the position of the cup by rotating the cup by α about X-axis, and rotating the cup anteriorly by β about the line Z = y·tanα (Figure 1).
Knowing the maximum angle of the rotational movement in the cup (A), where A = 360 −ic (Figure 1), allows the coordinates of the point of impingement on the cup to be defined as

The site of impingement on the neck can be determined by a vector with a magnitude equal to the point of impingement on the cup. Given that the radial coordinate of the neck’s cross section, r, is a known function of the polar angle, θ, about the shafts centreline, the position (Figure 3) where the neck axis is pointing in the positive y direction (Figure 4), any point on the neck B0(x0, y0, z0) can be defined as

Therefore, the neck’s starting position can be determined by rotating B0 by a degrees about the X-axis in a clockwise direction (x1, y1, z1), and again by b degrees about the Z-axis in an anti-clockwise direction (x2, y2, z2). This defines the starting position of the neck (Figure 2)

sec.title: Flexion–extension
sec.p: If the neck is rotated in isolation about any of the flexion–extension axes, the position of any point on the neck will have a constant y coordinate. Combining this information with equations (1), (4) and (6) allows three simultaneous quadratic equations to be derived, of which the three unknowns are the coordinates of the two intersecting points of the cup rim and the neck (Figure 5).
where

The rotation of the neck from its starting position until impingement can be determined by calculating the dot product of the vector defining the starting position of the neck (equation (6)) and that defining the site of impingement on the cup. If these equations are solved for each point on the femoral neck where impingement is possible, the actual rotation before impingement will be the resulting functions’ minima

Therefore, flexion before impingement can be defined as
Similarly, extension can be defined as

When calculating the rotation, it is important to remember that the dot product will not indicate sign of angles above 180°; therefore, it may be necessary to calculate the cross product of the vectors in order to determine that actual values. The need for this will be apparent as the rotation-θ curve will have a discontinuity at 180°.
If the discriminant of the quadratic equation, D, is less than 0, then there is no impingement.

sec.title: Internal–external rotation
sec.p: If the neck is rotated in isolation about the internal–external rotation axes, the position of any point on the neck will have a constant z coordinate. In a manner similar to that outlined for flexion–extension, combining this information with equations (1), (4) and (6) allows three simultaneous quadratic equations to be derived, of which the three unknowns are the coordinates of the two intersecting points of the cup rim and the neck (Figure 6).

caption.p: Left hip replacement, the point of impingement on the cup and a circle illustrating rotation of a chosen point on the femoral neck about the Z-axis. The internal and external rotation angles where the chosen point of the neck will impinge on the cup are shown as ∠LDB and ∠MDB, respectively.

sec.p: where

The rotation of the neck from its starting position until impingement can be determined by calculating the dot product of the vector defining the starting position of the neck (equation (6)) and that defining the site of impingement on the cup. Therefore, internal rotation can be written as
External rotation can be written as
Again, if the discriminant of the quadratic equation, D, is less than 0°, then there is no impingement.

sec.title: Abduction–adduction
sec.p: If the neck is rotated in isolation about the abduction–adduction axes, the position of any point on the neck will have a constant x coordinate. In a manner to that outlined for flexion–extension, combining this information with equations (1), (4) and (6) allows three simultaneous quadratic equations to be derived, of which the three unknowns are the coordinates of the two intersecting points of the cup rim and the neck (Figure 7).

caption.p: Left hip replacement, the point of impingement on the cup and a circle illustrating rotation of a chosen point on the femoral neck about the X-axis. The abduction and adduction angles where the chosen point of the neck will impinge on the cup are shown as ∠LEB and ∠MEB, respectively.

sec.p: where

The rotation of the neck from its starting position until impingement can be determined by calculating the dot product of the vector defining the starting position of the neck (equation (6)) and that defining the site of impingement on the cup. Therefore, abduction can be written as
Similarly, adduction can be written as
If the discriminant of the quadratic equation, D, is less than 0°, then there is no impingement.

sec.title: External and internal rotation at 90° of flexion
sec.p: The external and internal rotational movement before impingement with a flexion of 90° (Figure 8) can be calculated using the equations defining abduction and adduction if the vector B is rotated by −90° about the Y-axis, giving vector Bfl90.

caption.p: Left hip replacement, the point of impingement on the cup and a circle illustrating rotation of a chosen point on the femoral neck about the X-axis. The internal and external rotation angles, with the femur flexed to 90°, where the chosen point of the neck will impinge on the cup are shown as ∠LFB and ∠MFB, respectively.

sec.p: Therefore

sec.title: Precise definition of the free-form neck geometry

caption.p: The perimeter of the free-form neck’s cross section given in polar coordinates

sec.title: Symmetry of cup–neck contact point
sec.p: As with the original equations, this analysis is based on the assumption that the point of impingement on the cup must be axisymmetric about an axis that passes through the joints’ rotation centre. This may be invalid if the cross section of the neck changes along its length or if the detailed design of the cup rim causes the radius of the point of neck impingement, |G|, to vary with neck radius. This assumption can be tested by using the equivalent oscillation angle (Figure 9) of the prosthesis, as a function of rim profile and neck radius, to identify if |G| is constant for the design being analysed. Considering a section of an axisymmetric cup design (Figure 9), the maximum angle of the rotational movement in the cup, A, a point of the rim profile, can be described as

caption.p: Illustration of a cup that is axisymetrical about the Z-axis with a chamfered rim of angle ω. Any point on the rim can be defined as point Pn(ycup, zcup) with radius |G| making the angle A/2 with the axis of symmetry. OD is the outside diameter of the cup, ID is the inside diameter of the cup, ZID is the offset of the start of the rim profile from the bearing rotation centre and ω is the angle the rim chamfer makes with the Y-axis.

sec.p: where
Moreover, the rim profile is defined as a function of yrim and zrim relative to the point where the cups’ inside diameter (ID) joins the rim profile. For the chamfer show
From this, the equivalent oscillation angle, OA, for each two-dimensional section of the cup can be calculated using the equation provided by Yoshimine and Ginbayashi4

The variation of OA can be evaluated as a function of |G| and r, and if the minima occur at the same value of |G| for all r, then the assumption that the point of impingement on the cup must be axisymmetric about the neck shaft centreline is valid.

Vector defining a position on the neck cross section’s perimeter
Vector with magnitude equal to the radius of the point of cup impingement
Vector defining the neutral position of the cup
Radial coordinate of the neck’s cross section
Point coordinates in the global coordinate system X, Y, Z that’s origin is the centre of the head
Point coordinates of vector B in the neutral position
Point coordinates of nth point on the rim profile
Point coordinates of the nth point relative to the point the bearing surface joints the rim
Offset of the start of the rim profile from the bearing rotation centre
Polar angle of the neck’s cross section
